item.title: Creating a Release from a Bugfix Branch
item.dc:creator: Software Development Training LLC
item.description:
Table of Contents

  • Assumptions
  • Steps

Assumptions

  • All changes to be included in the release have been made on the bugfix-branch
  • The bugfix-branch is a branch off of a release-branch (e.g. release/v3.25.0)

Steps

  1. Commit all your changes on the bugfix-branch

  2. Check out the release-branch (the branch that the bugfix-branch came off of in the first place).

    $ git checkout release/v3.25.0

  3. Create and checkout a new branch which will contain the bugfix changes and the release. We'll call this new branch the bugfix-release branch.

    $ git branch release/v3.25.1    # create the bugfix-release branch
$ git checkout release/v3.25.1  # checkout the bugfix-release branch

  4. Merge the bugfix-branch changes into the bugfix-release branch and squash the changes into one big change set.

    $ git merge --squash bugfix-branch

  5. Fix up the version.txt file

    $ git_current_branch > version.txt
$ git add version.txt

    Note: git_current_branch should be an alias defined as:

    $ alias git_current_branch='git symbolic-ref -q HEAD --short'

  6. Commit all changes to the bugfix-release branch

    $ git commit -m "Big description of the bugfix changes"

    Now all the changes from the bugfix-branch are in the bugfix-release (e.g. release/v3.25.1) branch.

  7. Push everything to the origin (GitHub)

    $ git push origin --all

  8. Remove the local bugfix-branch whose changes you've now merged and committed to the bugfix-release branch.

    $ git branch -D bugfix-branch

  9. Remove the remote bugfix-branch from the origin repository (GitHub)

    $ git push origin --delete bugfix-branch

  10. Create a tag in the bugfix-release branch

    $ git checkout *<bugfix-release>*
$ git checkout release/v3.25.1
$ git_current_branch > version.txt
$ git add version.txt
$ git commit -m "Created v3.25.1"
$ git tag -a v3.25.1 -m "Tagging v3.25.1"
$ git push --tags origin release/v3.25.1

  11. Go to https://github.com, log in, and create a release from the tag

    Releases --> Draft a new release --> Select tag

    • Provide a Title and Description
    • Publish the release

  12. Make sure you don't leave your local git repository with the release branch checked out.

    You do not want to make further changes to that branch.

    Also, you most likely (but not always) want your bug fix to go into the master branch so that it gets included in any future releases.

    $ git checkout master
$ git merge release/v3.25.1 # substitute your bugfix release
$ git_current_branch > version.txt
$ git add version.txt
$ git commit -m "Updated version.txt"
$ git push origin --all

  13. As always, further feature changes should go in a feature branch (off of master) and further bugfix changes should go in a bugfix branch (off of the release for which the bugs are being fixed).

item.title: Revert file in a release to version in a previous release
item.dc:creator: Software Development Training LLC
item.description:
Table of Contents

  • Example Situation
  • Steps

Example Situation

We have a file, FreeSurfer/FreeSurferPipeline.sh, that was released with version v3.25.0 (from branch release/v3.25.0 that needs to be reverted to the state it was in in version v3.24.0 (branch release/v3.25.0. We need to use this reverted file as part of a bugfix release, v3.25.1, that is from a branch off of release/v3.25.0.

Steps

  1. Checkout the release on which you are going to base the bugfix release (release/v3.25.0)

    $ git checkout release/v3.25.0

  2. Create and checkout a new branch that is based upon the currently checked out branch

    $ git branch revert-freesurfer-6-changes
$ git checkout revert-freesurfer-6-changes

  3. Make changes in the new branch and commit them

    In this case, the change is to overwrite a file in the branch with the same file from another branch. The other branch in this case is the previous release branch (release/v3.24.0).

    $ git checkout *<other-branch>* *<file>*
$ git checkout release/v3.24.0 FreeSurfer/FreeSurferPipeline.sh
$ git commit -m "Reverted FreeSurfer/FreeSurferPipeline.sh to the code released with version v3.24.0"

  4. Verify changes

    See Comparing versions of a file between 2 Git Branches

    $ git difftool revert-freesurfer-6-changes release/v3.25.0 FreeSurfer/FreeSurferPipeline.sh

    Should show changes because file has been overwritten.

    $ git difftool release/v3.24.0 revert-freesurfer-6-changes FreeSurfer/FreeSurferPipelinesh

    Should show no changes because the version in branch revert-freesurfer-6-changes should now be the same as that in branch release/v3.24.0.

  5. Create a bugfix release

    See Creating a Release from a Bugfix Branch

item.dc:creator: Software Development Training LLC
item.description:
Table of Contents

  • Command
  • Notes

Command

git diff branch1 branch2 path/to/myfile.ext

or

git difftool branch1 branch2 path/to/myfile.ext

Notes

  1. If the files are identical, the command will silently return, show no output, and not start any external tool.

item.dc:creator: Software Development Training LLC
item.description:
Table of Contents

  • Assumptions
  • Useful Links
  • Steps

Assumptions

  • You are using Git from Ubuntu/Debian Linux

Useful Links

  • Stackoverflow question about saving credentials
  • Git Credentials Documentation

Steps

  1. Add the git-core Personal Package Archive (PPA) repository

    $ sudo add-apt-repository ppa:git-core/ppa

  2. Download package lists for repositories and update them to get newest versions of packages

    $ sudo apt-get update

  3. Install the latest version of git

    $ sudo apt-get install git

item.title: How to save remote username and password for Git
item.dc:creator: Software Development Training LLC
item.description:
Table of Contents

  • Assumptions
  • Useful Links
  • Steps

Assumptions

  • You are using Git version 2.16.2 or greater

Useful Links

  • Stackoverflow question about saving credentials
  • Git Credentials Documentation

Steps

  1. Configure the credential helper for the repository to be the store helper

    The store helper stores the credentials in a user readable only file after the credentials are supplied once.

    $ git config credential.helper 'store --file=/home/*my-account*/.git-credentials-WUSTL'

    or

    $ git config credential.helper 'store --file=/home/*my-account*/.git-credentials-PERSONAL'

  2. Issue a command that requires the credentials

    $ git push origin --all # supply username and password as prompted

    If the credentials have already been stored in the specified file, then they will be used.

    If the credentials have not already been stored in the specified file, then the username and password will then be stored in the specified file. Next time they are needed, they will be retrieved from the store (the file) and you will no longer need to supply them.

  3. To reset them, you can delete the specified store file and issue a command that requires the credentials.

item.title: Creating a Release from a Feature Branch
item.dc:creator: Software Development Training LLC
item.description:
Table of Contents

  • Assumptions
  • Steps

Assumptions

  • All changes to be included in the release have been made on the feature-branch
  • We release from the master branch by merging feature-branch into the master branch
  • A feature release (e.g. X.Y.0) gets a branch of its own off of the master

Steps

  1. Commit all your changes on the feature-branch

  2. Merge the master branch into the feature-branch and get all conflicts resolved.

    This is in case any changes were made in the master branch since the point at which the feature-branch was branched off from the master

    $ git checkout feature-branch
$ git merge master

  3. Merge the feature-branch into the master branch and squash the changes into one big change set.

    This is to get the feature-branch changes into the master for use in the release and to ensure that these changes are included in any subsequent feature change branches. (Since feature change branches should be branches off of the master.) The squashing means that all the changes for the current feature will be under one commit comment.

    $ git checkout master
$ git merge --squash feature-branch

  4. Fix up the version.txt file -- make it say master

    $ git_current_branch > version.txt
$ get add version.txt

    Note: git_current_branch should be an alias defined as:

    alias git_current_branch='git symbolic-ref -q HEAD --short'

  5. Commit all changes to the master branch. This is the one commit for all of the feature-related changes

    $ git commit -m "Big description of feature branch changes"

    Now all the changes you made in feature-branch are in the master branch.

  6. Push everything to the origin (GitHub)

    $ git push origin --all

  7. Remove the local feature-branch whose changes you've now merged and committed to the master branch.

    $ git branch -D feature-branch

  8. Remove the remote feature-branch from the origin repository (GitHub)

    $ git push origin --delete feature-branch

  9. Create a release version in a release branch

    $ git checkout master
$ git branch release/v1.7.0  # substitute your intended release number
$ git checkout release/v1.7.0
$ git_current_branch > version.txt
$ git add version.txt
$ git commit -m "Created v1.7.0"
$ git tag -a v1.7.0 -m "Tagging v1.7.0"
$ git push --tags origin release/v1.7.0

  10. Go to https://github.com, log in, and create a release from the tag

    Releases --> Draft a new release --> Select tag

    • Provide a Title: e.g. "Multirun ICA+fIX on 7T Retinotopy Data"
    • Provide a Description: e.g. "This release is intended to be used for running Multirun ICA+FIX processing on 7T Retinotopy data"
    • Publish the release

  11. Make sure you don't leave your local git repository with the release branch checked out.

    You do not want to make further changes to that branch. If you are making a bugfix release (a final point release, e.g. v1.7.1 or v1.7.2), you will create a feature/bugfix branch off of the release branch.

    $ git checkout master

  12. Make sure all the changes in the release branch are merged into the master branch and the master branch is ready to use as a starting point for future changes.

    $ git merge release/v1.7.0 # substitute your release number
$ git_current_branch > version.txt
$ git add version.txt
$ git commit -m "Updated version.txt"
$ git push origin --all

  13. Further changes should be done in a new feature branch, not on the master branch.

item.title: Setting up Nikola, Git, and git-ftp
item.dc:creator: Software Development Training LLC
item.description:
Table of Contents

  • Useful Links
  • Assumptions
  • Substitutions in commands
  • Installation of Nikola
  • Associating your site source code with a GitHub Repository
  • Building and viewing your site locally
  • Preparing to deploy your site using git-ftp
  • Make a change to your content and build your site locally
  • Deploy your site
  • Notes

Useful Links

  • Nikola Getting Started Guide
  • The Nikola Handbook
  • git-ftp

Assumptions

The following assumes:

  • You already have a Python 3 environment set up using Anaconda.
  • You have git version 2.16.2 or later installed
  • You are working with your Python 3 and git tools at a bash shell

Substitutions in commands

Make the following substitutions in the commands below:

  • Substitute your Python 3 environment name for python3
  • Substitute the name of the directory in which you keep your source code projects for ~/projects
  • Substitute the sub-directory of ~/projects you want to use for the source code for your site for softdevtrain.com.

Installation of Nikola

  1. Start your Python 3 environment

    $ source activate python3

  2. Install prerequisite Python "Asset management application for Python web development"

    (python3) $ pip install webassets

  3. Ensure that pip and setuptools are up-to-date

    (python3) $ pip install --upgrade setuptools pip --ignore-installed

  4. Install Nikola

    (python3) $ pip install --upgrade "Nikola[extras]" --ignore-installed

Associating your site source code with a GitHub Repository

If you are starting a completely new site

  1. Create a GitHub repository for your site

    • Visit <https://github.com> and login to your GitHub account.
    • Select the New repository button
    • Name the repository softdevtrain.com (your site name)

    You should see the GitHub URL for your new (empty) repository. (e.g. https://github.com/your-user-id/softdevtrain.com.git)

  2. Clone your new (empty) GitHub repository

    (python3) $ cd ~/projects
(python3) $ git clone https://github.com/your-user-id/softdevtrain.com.git

  3. Verify that the ~/projects/softdevtrain.com directory has been created

  4. Initialize your site

    (python3) $ cd ~/projects
(python3) $ nikola init softdevtrain.com

    This should create the first version of your site in the softdevtrain.com sub-directory.

If you are working with a site for which a GitHub repository has already been created

  1. Clone the existing GitHub repository

    (python3) $ cd ~/projects
(python3) $ git clone https://github.com/your-user-id/softdevtrain.com.git

Building and viewing your site locally

  1. Build your site

    (python3) $ cd ~/projects/softdevtrain.com
(python3) $ nikola build

  2. View your site

    (python3) $ gnome-open output/index.html

    or

    (python3) $ nikola serve -b
    Ctrl-C when done

Preparing to deploy your site using git-ftp

Install git-ftp

(python3) $ sudo apt-get install git-ftp

Configure git-ftp

(python3) $ git config git-ftp.url "ftp://your-ftp-site/your-files-directory"
(python3) $ git config git-ftp.user "your-ftp-site-user-id"
(python3) $ git config git-ftp.password "your-ftp-site-password"
(python3) $ git config git-ftp.syncroot output/ # the output directory of a Nikola repository contains the built site to be deployed

Make a change to your content and build your site locally

For example:

(python3) $ nikola new_post

or

(python3) $ nikola new_post -e # make a new post and open up the editor specified in the EDITOR environment variable

Edit your post or content.

Then build the site with the following command:

(python3) $ nikola build

Deploy your site

If you have not uploaded any files to the ftp site and you want to completely upload all files to your site.

(python3) $ git ftp init

If you have previously uploaded files to your ftp site.

(python3) $ git ftp push

Notes

  1. Pushing to the ftp site does not cause the changes to be committed to your local repository or pushed to the origin remote repository.

    You will need to do git commit -m "comment" to commit changes locally before they can be pushed to the ftp site.

    You will need to do git push origin --all (or a similar command) to push your changes to the git repository.

  2. Your standard operating procedure after setup will usually be:

    Make or edit a post or page

    (python3) $ nikola new_post

    Build the site locally to see how your changes look

    (python3) $ nikola build

    See if it looks like what you like

    (python3) $ gnome-open output/index.html

    or

    (python3) $ nikola serve -b
Ctrl-C when done

    Commit changes to local repository and push them to remote (GitHub) repository

    (python3) $ git add *files*
(python3) $ git commit -m "commit comment"
(python3) $ git push origin --all

    Push the changes to the ftp site so they actually show up on your web site

    (python3) $ git ftp push
